question_text: Calculate the theoretical energy requirement for producing ethylene from polyethylene chains, considering both bond breaking and formation energies, and explain how this thermodynamic constraint affects process design.
standard_answer: The energy requirement for ethylene production from polyethylene involves breaking one C-C σ-bond (BDE ≈ 346 kJ/mol) and forming one C=C π-bond (bond energy ≈ 256 kJ/mol). The net enthalpy change ΔH = 346 - 256 = 90 kJ/mol ethylene. This significant endothermicity dictates several process design considerations: (1) High temperature operation (750-900°C) is necessary to provide sufficient thermal energy for bond scission; (2) Efficient heat transfer mechanisms must be implemented to supply the required energy; (3) The process is inherently energy-intensive, making thermal integration crucial for economic viability; (4) Secondary reactions that produce methane and hydrogen become more favorable at higher temperatures due to their even more endothermic nature. The thermodynamic constraint explains why catalytic routes are pursued to lower activation barriers, and why reactor designs must optimize heat transfer while minimizing energy losses through insulation and efficient heating methods.
